Nib
  • Nib  
  • nib.views.charts.marks module

nib.views.charts.marks module

Chart mark classes for Nib Charts.

This module provides mark classes that define how data is visually represented in charts. Marks are the visual elements of a chart - lines, bars, areas, points, and other shapes that encode data values.

Each mark type maps data fields to visual properties. For example, a LineMark maps x and y data fields to positions along a line, while a BarMark maps fields to bar heights and positions.

Marks support visual customization through properties like foreground_style (color), opacity, and mark-specific options like line_width or corner_radius.

Available Marks:

  • LineMark: Line charts with optional symbols and interpolation

  • BarMark: Vertical or horizontal bar charts with stacking support

  • AreaMark: Filled area charts with stacking and interpolation

  • PointMark: Scatter plots with customizable symbols

  • RuleMark: Reference lines (horizontal or vertical)

  • RectMark: Rectangle marks for heatmaps and range visualizations

  • SectorMark: Pie and donut chart segments

Example

Simple line chart mark:

mark = LineMark(x="date", y="value")

Styled bar chart mark:

mark = BarMark(
    x="category",
    y="sales",
    foreground_style="blue",
    corner_radius=4,
)

Multi-series with color encoding:

mark = LineMark(
    x="date",
    y="value",
    foreground_style=PlottableField("series"),  # Color by series
)
class nib.views.charts.marks.BaseMark(foreground_style=None, opacity=None)[source]

Bases: object

Base class for all chart marks.

BaseMark provides the common interface and functionality shared by all mark types. It handles common visual properties like foreground_style and opacity, and defines the serialization interface.

Subclasses should override _get_props() to add mark-specific properties while calling _get_base_props() to include the common properties.

This class is not meant to be instantiated directly. Use one of the concrete mark classes like LineMark, BarMark, etc.

_type

String identifier for the mark type, used in serialization.

Parameters:

  • foreground_style (Union[str, PlottableField, None])

  • opacity (Optional[float])

Initialize common mark properties.

Parameters:

  • foreground_style (Union[str, PlottableField, None]) Color or data field for the marks fill/stroke. Can be a hex color string (e.g., #FF5733), a named color (e.g., blue), or a PlottableField to encode color based on data values (for automatic color assignment per category).

  • opacity (Optional[float]) Opacity of the mark from 0.0 (transparent) to 1.0 (opaque). Defaults to None (uses system default, typically 1.0).

__init__(foreground_style=None, opacity=None)[source]

Initialize common mark properties.

Parameters:

  • foreground_style (Union[str, PlottableField, None]) Color or data field for the marks fill/stroke. Can be a hex color string (e.g., #FF5733), a named color (e.g., blue), or a PlottableField to encode color based on data values (for automatic color assignment per category).

  • opacity (Optional[float]) Opacity of the mark from 0.0 (transparent) to 1.0 (opaque). Defaults to None (uses system default, typically 1.0).

to_dict(path='0')[source]

Convert mark to dictionary for serialization.

Produces a dictionary representation suitable for sending to the Swift runtime via MessagePack.

Parameters:

path (str) The path identifier for this mark in the view tree. Defaults to 0.

Return type:

dict

Returns:

Dictionary containing the marks id, type, and properties.

class nib.views.charts.marks.LineMark(x, y, foreground_style=None, symbol=None, interpolation=None, line_width=None, opacity=None)[source]

Bases: BaseMark

Line mark for creating line charts.

LineMark connects data points with a continuous line, ideal for showing trends over time or continuous relationships between variables. Lines can be styled with different colors, widths, and interpolation methods.

Optionally, symbols (markers) can be added at each data point for better visibility of individual values.

Example

Basic line chart:

LineMark(x="date", y="temperature")

Styled line with symbols:

LineMark(
    x="month",
    y="sales",
    foreground_style="#3B82F6",
    symbol=SymbolShape.CIRCLE,
    line_width=2.0,
    interpolation=InterpolationMethod.MONOTONE,
)

Multi-series line chart (color by category):

LineMark(
    x="date",
    y="value",
    foreground_style=PlottableField("series"),
)
Parameters:

  • x (Union[str, PlottableField])

  • y (Union[str, PlottableField])

  • foreground_style (Union[str, PlottableField, None])

  • symbol (Union[str, SymbolShape, PlottableField, None])

  • interpolation (Union[str, InterpolationMethod, None])

  • line_width (Optional[float])

  • opacity (Optional[float])

Initialize a LineMark.

Parameters:

  • x (Union[str, PlottableField]) Data field for the x-axis position. Can be a string field name or a PlottableField for additional type information.

  • y (Union[str, PlottableField]) Data field for the y-axis position. Can be a string field name or a PlottableField for additional type information.

  • foreground_style (Union[str, PlottableField, None]) Line color. Can be a hex color string, named color, or PlottableField to color lines by a data category.

  • symbol (Union[str, SymbolShape, PlottableField, None]) Shape for data point markers. Can be a SymbolShape enum value (CIRCLE, SQUARE, TRIANGLE, etc.), a string, or a PlottableField to vary symbols by data category.

  • interpolation (Union[str, InterpolationMethod, None]) Method for interpolating between points. Options include LINEAR, MONOTONE, CATMULL_ROM, CARDINAL, STEP_START, STEP_CENTER, and STEP_END. Defaults to LINEAR.

  • line_width (Optional[float]) Width of the line in points. Defaults to system default.

  • opacity (Optional[float]) Opacity from 0.0 to 1.0. Defaults to 1.0.

__init__(x, y, foreground_style=None, symbol=None, interpolation=None, line_width=None, opacity=None)[source]

Initialize a LineMark.

Parameters:

  • x (Union[str, PlottableField]) Data field for the x-axis position. Can be a string field name or a PlottableField for additional type information.

  • y (Union[str, PlottableField]) Data field for the y-axis position. Can be a string field name or a PlottableField for additional type information.

  • foreground_style (Union[str, PlottableField, None]) Line color. Can be a hex color string, named color, or PlottableField to color lines by a data category.

  • symbol (Union[str, SymbolShape, PlottableField, None]) Shape for data point markers. Can be a SymbolShape enum value (CIRCLE, SQUARE, TRIANGLE, etc.), a string, or a PlottableField to vary symbols by data category.

  • interpolation (Union[str, InterpolationMethod, None]) Method for interpolating between points. Options include LINEAR, MONOTONE, CATMULL_ROM, CARDINAL, STEP_START, STEP_CENTER, and STEP_END. Defaults to LINEAR.

  • line_width (Optional[float]) Width of the line in points. Defaults to system default.

  • opacity (Optional[float]) Opacity from 0.0 to 1.0. Defaults to 1.0.

class nib.views.charts.marks.BarMark(x=None, y=None, width=None, height=None, foreground_style=None, stacking=None, corner_radius=None, opacity=None)[source]

Bases: BaseMark

Bar mark for creating bar charts.

BarMark displays data as rectangular bars, ideal for comparing discrete categories or showing distribution of values. Bars can be oriented vertically (default) or horizontally, and support stacking for multi-series comparisons.

The orientation is determined by which fields are categorical vs. quantitative. For vertical bars, x is typically categorical and y is quantitative. For horizontal bars, swap the fields.

Example

Simple vertical bar chart:

BarMark(x="category", y="value")

Horizontal bar chart:

BarMark(x="value", y="category")

Stacked bar chart:

BarMark(
    x="month",
    y="sales",
    foreground_style=PlottableField("region"),
    stacking=StackingMethod.STANDARD,
)

Styled bars:

BarMark(
    x="product",
    y="revenue",
    foreground_style="#10B981",
    corner_radius=4,
)
Parameters:

  • x (Union[str, PlottableField, None])

  • y (Union[str, PlottableField, None])

  • width (Optional[float])

  • height (Optional[float])

  • foreground_style (Union[str, PlottableField, None])

  • stacking (Union[str, StackingMethod, None])

  • corner_radius (Optional[float])

  • opacity (Optional[float])

Initialize a BarMark.

Parameters:

  • x (Union[str, PlottableField, None]) Data field for the x-axis. For vertical bars, this is typically the categorical field. Can be None for single-value charts.

  • y (Union[str, PlottableField, None]) Data field for the y-axis. For vertical bars, this is typically the quantitative field (bar height). Can be None for single-value charts.

  • width (Optional[float]) Fixed width for bars in points. If not specified, bars are sized automatically based on available space.

  • height (Optional[float]) Fixed height for bars in points. If not specified, bars are sized based on the y data values.

  • foreground_style (Union[str, PlottableField, None]) Bar fill color. Can be a hex color, named color, or PlottableField to color bars by category (creates grouped or stacked bars).

  • stacking (Union[str, StackingMethod, None]) How to stack bars when multiple series overlap. Options: STANDARD (stacked), NORMALIZED (100% stacked), CENTER (centered). Defaults to None (no stacking, bars are grouped).

  • corner_radius (Optional[float]) Radius for rounded bar corners in points.

  • opacity (Optional[float]) Opacity from 0.0 to 1.0. Defaults to 1.0.

__init__(x=None, y=None, width=None, height=None, foreground_style=None, stacking=None, corner_radius=None, opacity=None)[source]

Initialize a BarMark.

Parameters:

  • x (Union[str, PlottableField, None]) Data field for the x-axis. For vertical bars, this is typically the categorical field. Can be None for single-value charts.

  • y (Union[str, PlottableField, None]) Data field for the y-axis. For vertical bars, this is typically the quantitative field (bar height). Can be None for single-value charts.

  • width (Optional[float]) Fixed width for bars in points. If not specified, bars are sized automatically based on available space.

  • height (Optional[float]) Fixed height for bars in points. If not specified, bars are sized based on the y data values.

  • foreground_style (Union[str, PlottableField, None]) Bar fill color. Can be a hex color, named color, or PlottableField to color bars by category (creates grouped or stacked bars).

  • stacking (Union[str, StackingMethod, None]) How to stack bars when multiple series overlap. Options: STANDARD (stacked), NORMALIZED (100% stacked), CENTER (centered). Defaults to None (no stacking, bars are grouped).

  • corner_radius (Optional[float]) Radius for rounded bar corners in points.

  • opacity (Optional[float]) Opacity from 0.0 to 1.0. Defaults to 1.0.

class nib.views.charts.marks.AreaMark(x, y, y_start=None, foreground_style=None, interpolation=None, stacking=None, opacity=None)[source]

Bases: BaseMark

Area mark for creating filled area charts.

AreaMark fills the region between a line and a baseline (typically zero or another line), creating a visual representation of cumulative values or ranges. Area charts are effective for showing magnitude over time and support stacking for multi-series data.

By default, the area extends from zero to the y value. Use y_start to create range areas or band charts.

Example

Basic area chart:

AreaMark(x="date", y="revenue")

Stacked area chart:

AreaMark(
    x="month",
    y="sales",
    foreground_style=PlottableField("category"),
    stacking=StackingMethod.STANDARD,
)

Range/band area:

AreaMark(
    x="date",
    y="high",
    y_start="low",
    foreground_style="#3B82F6",
    opacity=0.3,
)

Smooth area with custom interpolation:

AreaMark(
    x="date",
    y="value",
    interpolation=InterpolationMethod.MONOTONE,
)
Parameters:

  • x (Union[str, PlottableField])

  • y (Union[str, PlottableField])

  • y_start (Union[str, PlottableField, None])

  • foreground_style (Union[str, PlottableField, None])

  • interpolation (Union[str, InterpolationMethod, None])

  • stacking (Union[str, StackingMethod, None])

  • opacity (Optional[float])

Initialize an AreaMark.

Parameters:

  • x (Union[str, PlottableField]) Data field for the x-axis position.

  • y (Union[str, PlottableField]) Data field for the upper boundary of the area (y-axis).

  • y_start (Union[str, PlottableField, None]) Data field for the lower boundary of the area. If not specified, the area extends from zero (or the axis minimum) to the y value. Use this for range or band visualizations.

  • foreground_style (Union[str, PlottableField, None]) Fill color for the area. Can be a hex color, named color, or PlottableField for multi-series coloring.

  • interpolation (Union[str, InterpolationMethod, None]) Curve interpolation method. Options include LINEAR, MONOTONE, CATMULL_ROM, CARDINAL, and step variants.

  • stacking (Union[str, StackingMethod, None]) Stacking mode for multi-series areas. Options: STANDARD (stacked), NORMALIZED (100% stacked), CENTER (stream graph).

  • opacity (Optional[float]) Fill opacity from 0.0 to 1.0. Consider using lower opacity (0.3-0.7) for overlapping areas.

__init__(x, y, y_start=None, foreground_style=None, interpolation=None, stacking=None, opacity=None)[source]

Initialize an AreaMark.

Parameters:

  • x (Union[str, PlottableField]) Data field for the x-axis position.

  • y (Union[str, PlottableField]) Data field for the upper boundary of the area (y-axis).

  • y_start (Union[str, PlottableField, None]) Data field for the lower boundary of the area. If not specified, the area extends from zero (or the axis minimum) to the y value. Use this for range or band visualizations.

  • foreground_style (Union[str, PlottableField, None]) Fill color for the area. Can be a hex color, named color, or PlottableField for multi-series coloring.

  • interpolation (Union[str, InterpolationMethod, None]) Curve interpolation method. Options include LINEAR, MONOTONE, CATMULL_ROM, CARDINAL, and step variants.

  • stacking (Union[str, StackingMethod, None]) Stacking mode for multi-series areas. Options: STANDARD (stacked), NORMALIZED (100% stacked), CENTER (stream graph).

  • opacity (Optional[float]) Fill opacity from 0.0 to 1.0. Consider using lower opacity (0.3-0.7) for overlapping areas.

class nib.views.charts.marks.PointMark(x, y, foreground_style=None, symbol=None, symbol_size=None, opacity=None)[source]

Bases: BaseMark

Point mark for creating scatter plots.

PointMark displays individual data points as symbols, ideal for showing relationships between two quantitative variables or highlighting specific data points. Each point can be customized with different shapes, sizes, and colors.

PointMark is commonly used for scatter plots, bubble charts (with size encoding), and adding data point markers to other chart types.

Example

Basic scatter plot:

PointMark(x="height", y="weight")

Colored by category:

PointMark(
    x="sepal_length",
    y="sepal_width",
    foreground_style=PlottableField("species"),
)

Custom symbols and size:

PointMark(
    x="x",
    y="y",
    symbol=SymbolShape.DIAMOND,
    symbol_size=100,
    foreground_style="#EF4444",
)

Symbols varying by data:

PointMark(
    x="x",
    y="y",
    symbol=PlottableField("category"),  # Different symbol per category
)
Parameters:

  • x (Union[str, PlottableField])

  • y (Union[str, PlottableField])

  • foreground_style (Union[str, PlottableField, None])

  • symbol (Union[str, SymbolShape, PlottableField, None])

  • symbol_size (Optional[float])

  • opacity (Optional[float])

Initialize a PointMark.

Parameters:

  • x (Union[str, PlottableField]) Data field for the x-axis position.

  • y (Union[str, PlottableField]) Data field for the y-axis position.

  • foreground_style (Union[str, PlottableField, None]) Point fill color. Can be a hex color, named color, or PlottableField to color points by category.

  • symbol (Union[str, SymbolShape, PlottableField, None]) Shape of the point marker. Can be a SymbolShape enum (CIRCLE, SQUARE, TRIANGLE, DIAMOND, CROSS, PLUS, PENTAGON, HEXAGON), a string, or a PlottableField to vary symbols by data category.

  • symbol_size (Optional[float]) Size of the symbol in square points. Larger values create bigger markers. Defaults to system default.

  • opacity (Optional[float]) Opacity from 0.0 to 1.0. Useful for dense scatter plots where points overlap.

__init__(x, y, foreground_style=None, symbol=None, symbol_size=None, opacity=None)[source]

Initialize a PointMark.

Parameters:

  • x (Union[str, PlottableField]) Data field for the x-axis position.

  • y (Union[str, PlottableField]) Data field for the y-axis position.

  • foreground_style (Union[str, PlottableField, None]) Point fill color. Can be a hex color, named color, or PlottableField to color points by category.

  • symbol (Union[str, SymbolShape, PlottableField, None]) Shape of the point marker. Can be a SymbolShape enum (CIRCLE, SQUARE, TRIANGLE, DIAMOND, CROSS, PLUS, PENTAGON, HEXAGON), a string, or a PlottableField to vary symbols by data category.

  • symbol_size (Optional[float]) Size of the symbol in square points. Larger values create bigger markers. Defaults to system default.

  • opacity (Optional[float]) Opacity from 0.0 to 1.0. Useful for dense scatter plots where points overlap.

class nib.views.charts.marks.RuleMark(x=None, x_start=None, x_end=None, y=None, y_start=None, y_end=None, foreground_style=None, line_width=None, opacity=None)[source]

Bases: BaseMark

Rule mark for reference lines (horizontal or vertical).

RuleMark draws straight lines across the chart, useful for showing thresholds, averages, targets, or other reference values. Rules can be horizontal (fixed y, spanning x) or vertical (fixed x, spanning y).

Rules can also be bounded to create line segments between specific start and end points.

Example

Horizontal reference line (e.g., target line):

RuleMark(y=100, foreground_style="#EF4444", line_width=2)

Vertical reference line (e.g., event marker):

RuleMark(x="2024-06-15", foreground_style="#6366F1")

Bounded horizontal segment:

RuleMark(
    y=50,
    x_start="Jan",
    x_end="Jun",
    foreground_style="#10B981",
)

Data-driven rules (one rule per data point):

RuleMark(
    y="threshold",  # Field name - creates rule for each row
    foreground_style="#F59E0B",
)
Parameters:

  • x (Union[str, float, PlottableField, PlottableValue, None])

  • x_start (Union[str, float, PlottableField, PlottableValue, None])

  • x_end (Union[str, float, PlottableField, PlottableValue, None])

  • y (Union[str, float, PlottableField, PlottableValue, None])

  • y_start (Union[str, float, PlottableField, PlottableValue, None])

  • y_end (Union[str, float, PlottableField, PlottableValue, None])

  • foreground_style (Union[str, PlottableField, None])

  • line_width (Optional[float])

  • opacity (Optional[float])

Initialize a RuleMark.

Specify either x (for vertical line) or y (for horizontal line), along with optional start/end bounds.

Parameters:

  • x (Union[str, float, PlottableField, PlottableValue, None]) X-axis position for a vertical rule. Can be a static value (number), a field name (string), PlottableField, or PlottableValue.

  • x_start (Union[str, float, PlottableField, PlottableValue, None]) Starting x position when creating a bounded horizontal rule segment.

  • x_end (Union[str, float, PlottableField, PlottableValue, None]) Ending x position when creating a bounded horizontal rule segment.

  • y (Union[str, float, PlottableField, PlottableValue, None]) Y-axis position for a horizontal rule. Can be a static value (number), a field name (string), PlottableField, or PlottableValue.

  • y_start (Union[str, float, PlottableField, PlottableValue, None]) Starting y position when creating a bounded vertical rule segment.

  • y_end (Union[str, float, PlottableField, PlottableValue, None]) Ending y position when creating a bounded vertical rule segment.

  • foreground_style (Union[str, PlottableField, None]) Line color. Can be a hex color, named color, or PlottableField.

  • line_width (Optional[float]) Width of the rule line in points.

  • opacity (Optional[float]) Opacity from 0.0 to 1.0.

__init__(x=None, x_start=None, x_end=None, y=None, y_start=None, y_end=None, foreground_style=None, line_width=None, opacity=None)[source]

  • x_start (Union[str, float, PlottableField, PlottableValue, None]) Starting x position when creating a bounded horizontal rule segment.

  • x_end (Union[str, float, PlottableField, PlottableValue, None]) Ending x position when creating a bounded horizontal rule segment.

  • y (Union[str, float, PlottableField, PlottableValue, None]) Y-axis position for a horizontal rule. Can be a static value (number), a field name (string), PlottableField, or PlottableValue.

  • y_start (Union[str, float, PlottableField, PlottableValue, None]) Starting y position when creating a bounded vertical rule segment.

class nib.views.charts.marks.RectMark(x=None, x_start=None, x_end=None, y=None, y_start=None, y_end=None, foreground_style=None, corner_radius=None, opacity=None)[source]

Bases: BaseMark

Rectangle mark for heatmaps and range visualizations.

RectMark draws filled rectangles defined by their bounds in data space. It is ideal for creating heatmaps, Gantt charts, range visualizations, and other grid-based charts where each cell represents a data value.

Rectangles can be positioned using either center points (x, y) or explicit bounds (x_start/x_end, y_start/y_end).

Example

Heatmap cell (positioned by category):

RectMark(
    x="weekday",
    y="hour",
    foreground_style=PlottableField("intensity"),
)

Range/Gantt chart:

RectMark(
    x_start="start_date",
    x_end="end_date",
    y="task",
    foreground_style=PlottableField("status"),
    corner_radius=4,
)

Calendar heatmap:

RectMark(
    x="week",
    y="day_of_week",
    foreground_style=PlottableField("value"),
    corner_radius=2,
)
Parameters:

  • x (Union[str, PlottableField, None])

  • x_start (Union[str, PlottableField, None])

  • x_end (Union[str, PlottableField, None])

  • y (Union[str, PlottableField, None])

  • y_start (Union[str, PlottableField, None])

  • y_end (Union[str, PlottableField, None])

  • foreground_style (Union[str, PlottableField, None])

  • corner_radius (Optional[float])

  • opacity (Optional[float])

Initialize a RectMark.

Use x/y for categorical positioning (cells sized automatically) or x_start/x_end and y_start/y_end for explicit bounds.

Parameters:

  • x (Union[str, PlottableField, None]) Data field for the x-axis center position. Used for categorical grids where cell width is automatic.

  • x_start (Union[str, PlottableField, None]) Data field for the left edge of the rectangle.

  • x_end (Union[str, PlottableField, None]) Data field for the right edge of the rectangle.

  • y (Union[str, PlottableField, None]) Data field for the y-axis center position. Used for categorical grids where cell height is automatic.

  • y_start (Union[str, PlottableField, None]) Data field for the bottom edge of the rectangle.

  • y_end (Union[str, PlottableField, None]) Data field for the top edge of the rectangle.

  • foreground_style (Union[str, PlottableField, None]) Fill color for the rectangle. Can be a hex color, named color, or PlottableField to encode values as colors (essential for heatmaps).

  • corner_radius (Optional[float]) Radius for rounded corners in points.

  • opacity (Optional[float]) Opacity from 0.0 to 1.0.

__init__(x=None, x_start=None, x_end=None, y=None, y_start=None, y_end=None, foreground_style=None, corner_radius=None, opacity=None)[source]

Initialize a RectMark.

Use x/y for categorical positioning (cells sized automatically) or x_start/x_end and y_start/y_end for explicit bounds.

Parameters:

  • x (Union[str, PlottableField, None]) Data field for the x-axis center position. Used for categorical grids where cell width is automatic.

  • x_start (Union[str, PlottableField, None]) Data field for the left edge of the rectangle.

  • x_end (Union[str, PlottableField, None]) Data field for the right edge of the rectangle.

  • y (Union[str, PlottableField, None]) Data field for the y-axis center position. Used for categorical grids where cell height is automatic.

  • y_start (Union[str, PlottableField, None]) Data field for the bottom edge of the rectangle.

  • y_end (Union[str, PlottableField, None]) Data field for the top edge of the rectangle.

  • foreground_style (Union[str, PlottableField, None]) Fill color for the rectangle. Can be a hex color, named color, or PlottableField to encode values as colors (essential for heatmaps).

  • corner_radius (Optional[float]) Radius for rounded corners in points.

  • opacity (Optional[float]) Opacity from 0.0 to 1.0.

class nib.views.charts.marks.SectorMark(angle, foreground_style=None, inner_radius=None, outer_radius=None, angle_start=None, corner_radius=None, opacity=None)[source]

Bases: BaseMark

Sector mark for pie and donut charts.

SectorMark creates circular segments (wedges) based on angular data, perfect for showing proportional relationships and part-to-whole comparisons. By adjusting the inner radius, you can create donut charts instead of pie charts.

The angle field determines the size of each sector proportionally. Use foreground_style with a PlottableField to automatically assign colors to each category.

Example

Pie chart:

SectorMark(
    angle="value",
    foreground_style=PlottableField("category"),
)

Donut chart:

SectorMark(
    angle="percentage",
    foreground_style=PlottableField("segment"),
    inner_radius=50,
    outer_radius=100,
)

Styled donut with rounded segments:

SectorMark(
    angle="sales",
    foreground_style=PlottableField("region"),
    inner_radius=40,
    outer_radius=80,
    corner_radius=4,
)
Parameters:

  • angle (Union[str, PlottableField])

  • foreground_style (Union[str, PlottableField, None])

  • inner_radius (Optional[float])

  • outer_radius (Optional[float])

  • angle_start (Union[str, PlottableField, None])

  • corner_radius (Optional[float])

  • opacity (Optional[float])

Initialize a SectorMark.

Parameters:

  • angle (Union[str, PlottableField]) Data field containing values that determine sector sizes. Values are treated proportionally - a sector with value 20 will be twice as large as one with value 10.

  • foreground_style (Union[str, PlottableField, None]) Fill color for sectors. Use a PlottableField with a categorical field (e.g., category) to automatically assign different colors to each sector.

  • inner_radius (Optional[float]) Inner radius in points. Set to 0 for a pie chart, or a positive value for a donut chart. Defaults to 0.

  • outer_radius (Optional[float]) Outer radius in points. Defaults to automatic sizing based on available space.

  • angle_start (Union[str, PlottableField, None]) Data field or value for the starting angle of sectors. Rarely needed; use for custom sector positioning.

  • corner_radius (Optional[float]) Radius for rounded sector corners in points. Creates a softer visual appearance.

  • opacity (Optional[float]) Opacity from 0.0 to 1.0.

__init__(angle, foreground_style=None, inner_radius=None, outer_radius=None, angle_start=None, corner_radius=None, opacity=None)[source]

Initialize a SectorMark.

Parameters:

  • angle (Union[str, PlottableField]) Data field containing values that determine sector sizes. Values are treated proportionally - a sector with value 20 will be twice as large as one with value 10.

  • foreground_style (Union[str, PlottableField, None]) Fill color for sectors. Use a PlottableField with a categorical field (e.g., category) to automatically assign different colors to each sector.

  • inner_radius (Optional[float]) Inner radius in points. Set to 0 for a pie chart, or a positive value for a donut chart. Defaults to 0.

  • outer_radius (Optional[float]) Outer radius in points. Defaults to automatic sizing based on available space.

  • angle_start (Union[str, PlottableField, None]) Data field or value for the starting angle of sectors. Rarely needed; use for custom sector positioning.

  • corner_radius (Optional[float]) Radius for rounded sector corners in points. Creates a softer visual appearance.

  • opacity (Optional[float]) Opacity from 0.0 to 1.0.
